Award.AwardTitle: Evolution in Education: A Top Down Approach to Fundamentally Improving Science Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: In this project students of science collaborate with students of education in an interdisciplinary "learn-by-teaching" model to create lesson plans for elementary-school students. Using the content of organic evolution, newly introduced into Mississippi state education standards, students claim ownership of the material as they seek to understand it well enough to explain it to each other and to younger students. Focusing on the evolution of the nervous system, students enrolled in the biology course, Neuroscience, collaborate with students in the education course, Science in the Elementary School. Case studies prepared by science students are interpreted as lesson plans by education students and provided to in-service teachers. Students, course instructors, and in-service teachers compare these lesson plans to lesson plans prepared by standard methods, testing for the potential of plans to foster elementary students' understanding and enjoyment of the lessons. Successful aspects of this model can be applied to any course content and can be widely disseminated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Evolution in Education:

A Top Down Approach to Fundamentally Improve Science Education

            Building a community of educated citizens is impeded by the inability of scientists to communicate with the public and the difficulty educators have in translating complex science into simple, accurate lesson plans. Thus, faculty in Biology and Teacher Education departments tested the effectiveness of a novel teaching format that allowed science students and teaching candidates to collaborate in writing case studies for lay level readers and in formulating science lesson plans for 4th and 5th graders.

           Students in an Introductory Neuroscience course shared class sessions with teaching candidates in a Science in Elementary School course. Our methods could be used for any content area, but our focus was on brain and behavior adaptations in remarkable animals, a focus chosen because Mississippi had just adopted the National Science Teachers Association statement that evolutionary science is integral to science literacy. Because elementary teaching candidates in Mississippi and other states are expected to teach all elementary subjects, our initiative was devised to reduce the independent learning burden of education faculty and teaching candidates. Similarly, science students, often introduced to complex concepts near college-age, need assistance going beyond memorization to understanding.  Thus, we charged teaching candidates with helping science students to communicate core concepts in a simple and engaging manner.  Science students wrote draft case studies on animal adaptations (e.g. echolocation, electroreception) and collaborated with teaching candidates to improve communication. Teaching candidates subsequently developed lesson plans with feedback from science students. We evaluated improvements in case study drafts, tested pre and post content learning, compared the quality of lesson plans written on adaptation topics with a standard plan written on the scientific method, compared the quality of lesson plans written by a “control” group of teaching candidates that collaborated with other candidates rather than science students, and gathered qualitative and quantitative data on attitudes toward learning and the collaborations. In addition, a sample of lessons was evaluated for quality, scientific accuracy, and suitability for the classroom by in-practice teachers. Lastly, plan-specific scientific accuracy was judged by scientists with topic knowledge.

            Our initiative improved science students’ case study writing and increased topic knowledge. Yet, students were neutral to negative about their enjoyment of initiative activities.  Students may resist active learning even when they believe, and we know, it improves knowledge and writing outcomes. Regardless of collaboration type, writing adaptation lesson plans increased teaching candidates’ content knowledge and produced novel lesson plans that instructors judged to be on par with their performance on a standard lesson plan. Science student collaborations improved attitudes about science-writing compared to controls, but confidence, competence, and enthusiasm for teaching science were similar whether collaborations were with science students or other teaching candidates. Candidates made similar grades on adaptation and scientific method lesson plans.  However, the scientific accuracy scores of the candidates’ plans were not related to their grades on lesson plans.  Thus, academic rubrics for grading lesson plans assess various lesson topics similarly, but may not address scientific accuracy. Study participants that were interviewed suggested that both students and instructors find it difficult to prioritize scientific content knowledge over acquisition of general techniques for lesson plan that could benefit teaching across subjects. Faculty have initiated discussions to determine how to devise rubrics to incorporate scientific accuracy. Grading for scientific accuracy may be necessary to improve attitudes towards learning science and motivate engaged collaborations with science students. We continue evaluating modifications to the initiative to improve outcomes.

           Through implementing this initiative, we have developed a novel interdisciplinary teaching style and formulated joint syllabi for Education and Science classes that include the use of interactive response devices, blogging tools, and joint classroom exercises. Science students and teaching candidates were introduced to novel collaborations and unique topics. Students collaboratively produced 208 case studies and 183 lesson plans covering 8 topics related to animal adaptation. A PhD student in Biology, and a PhD and a MEd student in Teacher Education were mentored and trained in science content, pedagogy, and data collection and analyses. We conducted a small regional workshop to explore the implementation of our initiative at other academic institutions and enlisted in-practice teachers to evaluate the effectiveness of our lessons for future implementation in their classes. Lesson plans were shared with participating teachers, and we are preparing the best lesson plans for broader dissemination. We also pulled from the best case studies to create 5 fully developed cases for teaching many aspects of brain and behavior that will be published in an online forum.  Our work has been presented at several conferences and is being prepared for publication in scholarly journals.
